required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Toddler Overweight Prevention Study Among Low-Income Families
clinical_study.official_title: Toddler Overweight Prevention: Comparison of Maternal and Toddler Intervention

collaborator.agency: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD)

brief_summary.textblock: The hypothesis is that toddlers with parents who are randomized to a parenting intervention and toddlers with parents who are randomized to the maternal intervention focused on maternal diet and physical activity will be more likely to have weight status within normal and to consume a healthy diet and engage in physical activity than toddlers with parents in a placebo (safety) intervention.

detailed_description.textblock:
Background:
Overweight is a serious public health problem which can begin in early childhood. Factors which contribute to overweight include: overfeeding, excessive intakes of fat and sugar; frequent sedentary activities (i.e. television watching).
Overweight, defined as a BMI > 95th percentile, in early childhood has reached epidemic proportions with 14% of 2-5 year olds overweight and 26.2% "at risk of overweight," defined as a BMI > 85th percentile (Ogden et al., 2006).
Dietary and physical activity patterns established early in life track over time, making the first few years of life an ideal time to help families establish healthy eating and physical activity behaviors and avoid overweight. This project works to identify techniques that could prevent overweight.
Purpose of Study:
The investigators are collaborating with the Anne Arundel County, MD Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children (WIC) and the University of Maryland's Pediatric Ambulatory Center to implement strategies that will prevent overweight among toddlers. The project focuses on the dietary, physical activity, and growth patterns of WIC toddlers. The investigators are conducting a 3-cell randomized trial consisting of: 1) a maternal intervention focusing on healthy diet and physical activity patterns for mothers; 2) a toddler parenting intervention focusing on parenting, limit setting, and development strategies; and 3) an intervention on child safety. The interventions are implemented over 3 months, with 8 sessions.
The investigators hypothesize that altering maternal behavior will have a positive impact on the growth and development of the toddler by preventing behaviors that lead to overweight among children. The parenting intervention will improve parenting skills by offering information on proper approaches to feeding, discipline and educational play. The investigators will compare the growth patterns of toddlers whose mothers were randomized to the maternal and parenting interventions with those in the safety intervention. This study design allows us to examine the mechanisms linking the interventions to improvements in diet, physical activity, and growth.
In addition, the investigators will conduct the safety promotion intervention for the attention control group, considering the high risk of unintentional injuries among the toddlers from low-income families. The investigators also hypothesize that the safety promotion intervention will reduce the safety problems of the toddlers' homes. The underlying mechanisms will be examined, if there is a significant intervention effect.

primary_outcome.measure: Change of Body Mass Index (BMI) Z-score for Toddlers
primary_outcome.description: Measured weight and height for the toddlers, transferred to age and gender-specific body mass index (BMI) Z-score. The range of BMI z-score is usually between -5 and +5. BMI z-score lower than -1.645 is defined as underweight. The BMI z-score from -1.645 to 1.036 is normal weight and BMI z-score greater or equal to 1.645 is obese.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Body Mass Index (BMI) Score Among Mothers
primary_outcome.description: Change body mass index (BMI, kg/m^2, calculated by measured weight and height) from baseline to 12-month follow-up. The BMI ranges usually ranges from 0-50 with higher score indicating higher weight regarding the height. Scores above 25 are considered overweight and scores above 30 are considered obese.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of Diet Quality for Toddlers
secondary_outcome.description: Healthy Eating Index 2015 (HEI 2015) based on 24-hr diet recall. The range is 0-100, with higher scores representing better diet quality.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of Diet Quality for Mothers
secondary_outcome.description: Healthy Eating Index (HEI 15) is calculated based on 24 hour diet recall. Scores range from 0-100, with higher scores optimal

Physical activity is measured by wearing an accelerometer for 7 days. Using standards for toddlers, we count the number of minutes in moderate-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) per day, and averaged over the number of days measured, higher scores mean more physical activity.

Physical activity is measured by wearing an accelerometer for 7 days. Using standards for adults, we count the number of minutes in moderate-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) per day, and averaged over the number of days measured, higher scores mean more physical activity.

The Emotional Availability Scales (EAS) include 4 maternal scales (sensitivity, structuring, non-intrusiveness, and non-hostile) and 2 child scales (responsiveness and involvement), each rated on 7-point Likert scales, with high scores optimal. The maternal and child sub-scale scores were averaged for a total mealtime interaction score. The total score ranges from 1-7. Coders were trained until they demonstrated inter-rater reliability >0.80 based on intraclass correlation coefficients with 10 observations from the scale creator and 10 observations with the faculty coordinator. Inter-rater reliability was reviewed through weekly reliability checks.

arm_group.description: A maternal intervention focusing on healthy diet and physical activity patterns for mothers.
A toddler parenting intervention focusing on parenting, limit setting, and development strategies.
Attention control group. The parents received intervention to promote safety among toddlers.

intervention.description: At each session, mothers will identify a dietary goal for the next session (e.g., reduce soda intake). They will learn to track and evaluate their progress, setting new goals or modifying existing ones as necessary. Mothers will be given pedometers and shown how to keep a pedometer tracking chart. As with dietary choice, our objective is to have the mothers identify personal goals and strategies to achieve those goals, so they are more likely to continue to engage in physical activity after the intervention ends.

Behavior and Development Related to Diet and Physical Activity. The toddler parenting intervention will include modules on toddler behavior and development. We will devote sessions to topics involving parenting toddlers, limit setting, and child development.
The intervention will focus on child safety issues, including car seat safety, fire safety, fall prevention, and poison prevention. Participants will set weekly child safety goals.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- At least 18 yrs old
- Has child between 12-32 months
- Child able to walk
- Birth weight of child at least 5lbs. 8oz.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Mom cannot be pregnant
- No known congenital problems or disabilities

facility.name: University of Maryland, School of Medicine

reference.citation: Ogden CL, Carroll MD, Curtin LR, McDowell MA, Tabak CJ, Flegal KM. Prevalence of overweight and obesity in the United States, 1999-2004. JAMA. 2006 Apr 5;295(13):1549-55.

group.title: Maternal Lifestyle (Physical Activity and Nutrition)
group.description: A maternal lifestyle intervention focusing on healthy diet and physical activity patterns for mothers. Maternal Lifestyle (Physical Activity and Nutrition): At each session, mothers will identify a dietary goal for the next session (e.g., reduce soda intake). They will learn to track and evaluate their progress, setting new goals or modifying existing ones as necessary. Mothers will be given pedometers and shown how to keep a pedometer tracking chart. As with dietary choice, our objective is to have the mothers identify personal goals and strategies to achieve those goals, so they are more likely to continue to engage in physical activity after the intervention ends.

group.title: Responsive Parenting
group.description: A responsive parenting intervention focusing on parenting, limit setting, and development strategies. Responsive Parenting: Behavior and Development Related to Diet and Physical Activity. The toddler parenting intervention will include modules on toddler behavior and development. We will devote sessions to topics involving parenting toddlers, limit setting, and child development.

group.title: Child Safety
group.description: Attention control group. The parents received intervention to promote safety among toddlers. Child Safety: The intervention will focus on child safety issues, including car seat safety, fire safety, fall prevention, and poison prevention. Participants will set weekly child safety goals.

group.title: Maternal Lifestyle (Physical Activity and Nutrition)
group.description: A maternal lifestyle intervention focusing on healthy diet and physical activity patterns for mothers. Maternal Lifestyle (Physical Activity and Nutrition): At each session, mothers will identify a dietary goal for the next session (e.g., reduce soda intake). They will learn to track and evaluate their progress, setting new goals or modifying existing ones as necessary. Mothers will be given pedometers and shown how to keep a pedometer tracking chart. As with dietary choice, our objective is to have the mothers identify personal goals and strategies to achieve those goals, so they are more likely to continue to engage in physical activity after the intervention ends.

group.title: Responsive Parenting
group.description: A responsive parenting intervention focusing on parenting, limit setting, and development strategies. Responsive Parenting: Behavior and Development Related to Diet and Physical Activity. The toddler parenting intervention will include modules on toddler behavior and development. We will devote sessions to topics involving parenting toddlers, limit setting, and child development.

group.description: Attention control group. The parents received intervention to promote safety among toddlers. Child Safety: The intervention will focus on child safety issues, including car seat safety, fire safety, fall prevention, and poison prevention. Participants will set weekly child safety goals.

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measure.title: Household Poverty Ratio
measure.description: Household poverty ratio was calculated based on the federal poverty threshold for the year the data were collected using mother-reported total family income and number of household members. We summed the number of families with poverty ratio below 1, indicating that the average income for the family size is below the official definition of poverty.

measure.title: Maternal Education
measure.description: We calculated the number of mothers who had completed high school or the General Educational Development (GED) test.

measure.title: Maternal Marital Status
measure.description: Count of the number of mothers who were married

measure.title: Location (Urban/Semi-Urban)
measure.description: Families were recruited from 2 sites: urban and semi-urban. We counted the number of mothers from the urban site

measure.title: Maternal BMI
measure.description: Weight and height are measured to calculate BMI (kg/m^2).

measure.title: Toddler Body Mass Index (BMI) Z-score
measure.description: Body Mass Index, kg/m^2, is calculated by measured weight and height. BMI z-scores are measures of relative weight adjusted for child age and sex. The Z-score indicates the number of standard deviations away from a reference population in the same age range and with the same sex. These scores are used to determine weight status (e.g., overweight, obese, etc.)

outcome.title: Change of Body Mass Index (BMI) Z-score for Toddlers
outcome.description: Measured weight and height for the toddlers, transferred to age and gender-specific body mass index (BMI) Z-score. The range of BMI z-score is usually between -5 and +5. BMI z-score lower than -1.645 is defined as underweight. The BMI z-score from -1.645 to 1.036 is normal weight and BMI z-score greater or equal to 1.645 is obese.
outcome.population: Toddlers in low-income families, defined as WIC-eligible (income < 185% of poverty index). WIC=Special Supplementary Program for Women, Infants, and Children.

group.title: Maternal Lifestyle (Physical Activity and Nutrition)
group.description: A maternal lifestyle intervention focusing on healthy diet and physical activity patterns for mothers. Maternal Lifestyle (Physical Activity and Nutrition): At each session, mothers will identify a dietary goal for the next session (e.g., reduce soda intake). They will learn to track and evaluate their progress, setting new goals or modifying existing ones as necessary. Mothers will be given pedometers and shown how to keep a pedometer tracking chart. As with dietary choice, our objective is to have the mothers identify personal goals and strategies to achieve those goals, so they are more likely to continue to engage in physical activity after the intervention ends.

group.title: Responsive Parenting
group.description: A responsive parenting intervention focusing on parenting, limit setting, and development strategies. Responsive Parenting: Behavior and Development Related to Diet and Physical Activity. The toddler parenting intervention will include modules on toddler behavior and development. We will devote sessions to topics involving parenting toddlers, limit setting, and child development.

group.title: Child Safety
group.description: Attention control group. The parents received intervention to promote safety among toddlers. Child Safety: The intervention will focus on child safety issues, including car seat safety, fire safety, fall prevention, and poison prevention. Participants will set weekly child safety goals.

measure.title: Change of Body Mass Index (BMI) Z-score for Toddlers
measure.description: Measured weight and height for the toddlers, transferred to age and gender-specific body mass index (BMI) Z-score. The range of BMI z-score is usually between -5 and +5. BMI z-score lower than -1.645 is defined as underweight. The BMI z-score from -1.645 to 1.036 is normal weight and BMI z-score greater or equal to 1.645 is obese.
measure.population: Toddlers in low-income families, defined as WIC-eligible (income < 185% of poverty index). WIC=Special Supplementary Program for Women, Infants, and Children.

analysis.groups_desc: H0: There are no differences between the maternal lifestyle and child safety groups in the change in BMI z-score over time. Mixed models included the interaction between time and intervention, accounting for clustering of the repeated measures within each individual.
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: If the 95% confidence interval of the difference in the change over time does not include 0, it means that there is a significant difference in the change over time between the two groups.
analysis.p_value_desc: The alpha for statistical significance is set at 0.05.
analysis.estimate_desc: This is to compare change in maternal lifestyle group to child safety group.
This is to compare the Responsive Parenting to the safety intervention group.

outcome.title: Change in Body Mass Index (BMI) Score Among Mothers
outcome.description: Change body mass index (BMI, kg/m^2, calculated by measured weight and height) from baseline to 12-month follow-up. The BMI ranges usually ranges from 0-50 with higher score indicating higher weight regarding the height. Scores above 25 are considered overweight and scores above 30 are considered obese.
outcome.population: Mothers of toddlers participating in study, low-income, defined as WIC-eligible.

group.title: Maternal Lifestyle (Physical Activity and Nutrition)

group.description: Attention control group. The parents received intervention to promote safety among toddlers. Child Safety: The intervention will focus on child safety issues, including car seat safety, fire safety, fall prevention, and poison prevention. Participants will set weekly child safety goals.

measure.title: Change in Body Mass Index (BMI) Score Among Mothers
measure.description: Change body mass index (BMI, kg/m^2, calculated by measured weight and height) from baseline to 12-month follow-up. The BMI ranges usually ranges from 0-50 with higher score indicating higher weight regarding the height. Scores above 25 are considered overweight and scores above 30 are considered obese.
measure.population: Mothers of toddlers participating in study, low-income, defined as WIC-eligible.

analysis.groups_desc: H0: There is no difference between maternal lifestyle and child safety groups in the change of BMI over time.
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: 95% confidence interval (CI) was estimated. If the 95% CI does not include 0, it means there is significant difference in the change over time between the two groups.
analysis.p_value_desc: The alpha for statistical significance is set at 0.05
analysis.estimate_desc: This is to compare maternal lifestyle to child safety group.

analysis.groups_desc: H0: There are no differences in the change over time between responsive parenting and child safety groups.
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: The 95% CI was estimated. If it does not include 0, it means that there is a statistically significant difference in the change over time between the two groups.
analysis.p_value_desc: The alpha for statistical significance was set at 0.05.
analysis.estimate_desc: This is to compare the responsive parenting group to the child safety group.

outcome.title: Change of Diet Quality for Toddlers
outcome.description: Healthy Eating Index 2015 (HEI 2015) based on 24-hr diet recall. The range is 0-100, with higher scores representing better diet quality.
outcome.population: Change in HEI 2015 score for toddlers from baseline to 12 months

analysis.groups_desc: H0 is that there is no difference between maternal lifestyle and child safety groups in the change of HEI 2015 score over time.
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: The 95% confidence interval (CI) for the difference in the change over time was estimated. If it does not include 0, it indicates significant difference in the change over time.

analysis.groups_desc: H0 is that there is no difference between the responsive parenting and child safety groups in the change of HEI score over time

analysis.groups_desc: Null hypothesis is that there are no differences between the two groups regarding the change of HEI 2015 score over time.
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: The 95% CI was estimated. If it does not include 0, it indicates that there is significant difference in the change over time between the two groups.

outcome.title: Change of Child Physical Activity
outcome.description: Physical activity is measured by wearing an accelerometer for 7 days. Using standards for toddlers, we count the number of minutes in moderate-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) per day, and averaged over the number of days measured, higher scores mean more physical activity.
outcome.population: Toddlers who participated in the trial, from low-income families, defined as WIC-eligible

group.title: Maternal Lifestyle (Physical Activity and Nutrition)

measure.title: Change of Child Physical Activity
measure.description: Physical activity is measured by wearing an accelerometer for 7 days. Using standards for toddlers, we count the number of minutes in moderate-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) per day, and averaged over the number of days measured, higher scores mean more physical activity.
measure.population: Toddlers who participated in the trial, from low-income families, defined as WIC-eligible

analysis.groups_desc: Null hypothesis is there were no differences in the change over time for toddler MVPA across the two groups.
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: A 95% CI was estimated. If it does not include 0, it indicates significant difference in change over time between the two groups.
analysis.estimate_desc: This is for maternal lifestyle group compared to safety control group.

analysis.non_inferiority_desc: H0 is that there is no difference between the change of MVPA over time between the two groups.
analysis.estimate_desc: This is to compare the responsive parenting group to child safety group.

outcome.title: Change of Maternal Physical Activity
outcome.description: Physical activity is measured by wearing an accelerometer for 7 days. Using standards for adults, we count the number of minutes in moderate-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) per day, and averaged over the number of days measured, higher scores mean more physical activity.
outcome.population: Change in the number of steps per day from baseline to 12-month follow-up in MVPA

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse events were monitored over the time period that participants were actively participating in the study and assessments (e.g., 12 months for each participant or until the final assessment was completed).
reported_events.desc: Data Safety Monitoring Committee reviewed records and interviewed project coordinator.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: Data analysis was delayed due to extended period of time for coding the mother-toddler interaction data, related to personnel and funding.

point_of_contact.organization: University of Maryland School of Medicine
